title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the monetary base will increase by $50,000 and/or does not explain that the central bank bond purchase increases reserves by $50,000 and the monetary base is the sum of reserves and currency in circulation.

The response states that the monetary base will increase by $50,000 and explains that the central bank bond purchase increases reserves by $50,000 and the monetary base is the sum of reserves and currency in circulation.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the maximum change in the money supply as an increase of $1,000,000 and/or does not show the work.

Maximum Change in the Money Supply=$50,000× 1 0.05 =$1,000,000 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@6D81@

The response calculates the maximum change in the money supply as an increase of $1,000,000 and shows the work.

Maximum Change in the Money Supply=$50,000× 1 0.05 =$1,000,000 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@6D81@

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the change in nominal GDP as an increase of $2,000,000 and/or does not show the work.

Change in NGDP=Change in Money Supply×Velocity=$1,000,000×2=$2,000,000 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7835@

The response calculates the change in nominal GDP as an increase of $2,000,000 and shows the work.

Change in NGDP=Change in Money Supply×Velocity=$1,000,000×2=$2,000,000 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7835@

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that real output will stay the same in the long run and/or does not explain that when the economy is at full employment, changes in the money supply have no effect on real output in the long run.

The response states that real output will stay the same in the long run and explains that when the economy is at full employment, changes in the money supply have no effect on real output in the long run.
